quiz.title: Understanding Implementation Guides
quiz.description: Select profiles and implementation guides based on use cases, understand scope and relationships

questions.stem: What is the primary purpose of a FHIR Implementation Guide?

choices.label: To replace the base FHIR specification
To define how FHIR should be used for specific use cases or domains

questions.explanation: Implementation Guides provide domain-specific constraints, profiles, value sets, and guidance on how to use FHIR for particular use cases like US Core, cancer reporting, or clinical decision support.

questions.stem: You're building a US-based EHR system. Which Patient profile should you likely implement?
questions.explanation: US Core is the foundation implementation guide for US healthcare systems. It defines required elements and constraints for interoperability with US healthcare systems.

questions.stem: A custom Patient profile derives from US Core Patient Profile, which derives from base Patient. What constraint inheritance applies?

choices.label: Only the custom profile constraints apply
Constraints from all levels in the hierarchy apply
Custom profile overrides all parent constraints

questions.explanation: Profile constraints are additive through the inheritance hierarchy. A resource must conform to the base FHIR resource, the intermediate profile (US Core), and the custom profile constraints.

questions.stem: When should you choose a disease-specific IG (like IHE mCODE for cancer) over a general IG (like US Core)?

choices.label: Always use disease-specific IGs when available
When your use case specifically requires the specialized data elements

questions.explanation: Choose specialized IGs when your use case requires the specific data elements, workflows, or constraints they define. General IGs like US Core are suitable for broad interoperability.

questions.stem: Which conformance resources are typically found in Implementation Guides?
questions.explanation: IGs contain conformance resources that define how to use FHIR: StructureDefinitions (profiles), ValueSets, CodeSystems, CapabilityStatements, SearchParameters, and OperationDefinitions.

questions.stem: Your IG depends on US Core 5.0.1. What happens if you try to use it with US Core 4.0.0?

choices.label: There may be compatibility issues due to version differences
It will automatically upgrade US Core

questions.explanation: IG dependencies specify required versions for compatibility. Version mismatches can cause validation errors, missing elements, or changed constraints. Always use compatible versions.

questions.stem: What is the purpose of canonical URLs in profiles and implementation guides?

choices.label: To download the profile from the internet
To provide globally unique identifiers for profiles
To specify the FHIR server endpoint

questions.explanation: Canonical URLs provide globally unique, stable identifiers for profiles and other conformance resources. They enable unambiguous references and version management across systems.

questions.stem: In an Implementation Guide, mustSupport flags are defined differently for different systems. What should implementers do?

choices.label: Read the IG's specific mustSupport definition and requirements
Apply the same mustSupport rules for all IGs
Only implement mustSupport for servers, not clients

questions.explanation: mustSupport interpretation is IG-specific. Each IG should define what mustSupport means for implementers (servers and clients). Always read the IG's mustSupport documentation.

questions.stem: An IG defines an extension that can only be used on Patient resources. Where is this constraint specified?

choices.label: In the extension's StructureDefinition context element

questions.explanation: The StructureDefinition.context element defines where an extension can be used. It specifies the resource types, elements, or paths where the extension is valid.

questions.stem: How should you verify that your implementation conforms to an Implementation Guide?

choices.label: Manual review of the IG documentation
Use the IG's test plan and validation tools

questions.explanation: Well-defined IGs include test plans, example resources, and validation tools. Use these along with FHIR validators configured with the IG's profiles to verify conformance.
